clean somebody/something out.translation: to make the inside of a room, house etc clean or tidy
We’d better clean out the attic this week.
if something expensive cleans you out, you spend so much money on it that you now have very little left
Our trip to Paris cleaned me out.
to steal everything from a place, or all of someone’s possessions
to take all the money of a person or organization
The 16 bankrupt financial institutions threatened to clean out the central bank’s reserves.
to improve an organization by removing parts or people that are not making money or are not effective or honest
The banks must restructure to cut costs and clean out portfolios that are full of bad loans.
when an organization is improved by removing parts or people that are not making money or are not effective or honest
The country needs a clean-out of the balance sheets of its industrial companies.
